factoid: Everyone in the house realized the purpose of Prince Andrew's arrival.
Prince Andrew tried to be with Natásha all day.
In Natásha's soul, there was a feeling of awe at something important that was bound to happen.
In the whole house, there was a feeling of awe at something important that was bound to happen.
Countess Hélène looked at Prince Andrew with sad and sternly serious eyes when he talked to Natásha.
Countess Hélène started an artificial conversation about trifles as soon as she looked at Natásha.
Prince Andrew looked at Natásha when he talked to her.
Prince Andrew looked at Natásha.
Sónya was afraid to leave Natásha and afraid of being in the way when she was with them.
Natásha grew pale in a panic of expectation when she remained alone with Prince Andrew for a moment.
Prince Andrew surprised Natásha with his timidity.
Natásha felt that Prince Andrew wanted to say something to her but could not bring himself to do so.
In the evening, when Prince Andrew had left, Countess Hélène whispered “Well, what?” to Natásha.
Natásha said “Mamma! For heaven’s sake don’t ask me anything now! One can’t talk about that.”
Natásha lay a long time in her mother’s bed gazing straight before her.
Natásha told her mother that Prince Andrew had complimented her.
Natásha told her mother that Prince Andrew told her he was going abroad.
Natásha told her mother that Prince Andrew asked her where they were going to spend the summer.
Natásha told her mother that Prince Andrew had asked her about Borís.
Natásha said “But such a... such a... never happened to me before!”
Natásha said “Only I feel afraid in his presence. I am always afraid when I’m with him. What does that mean? Does it mean that it’s the real thing? Yes? Mamma, are you asleep?”
Natásha’s mother said “No, my love; I am frightened myself.”
Natásha’s mother said “Now go!”

Natásha said “All the same I shan’t sleep. What silliness, to sleep! Mummy! Mummy! such a thing never happened to me before,” and she was surprised and alarmed at the feeling she was aware of in herself.
Natásha said “And could we ever have thought!...”
It seemed to Natásha that even at the time she first saw Prince Andrew at Otrádnoe she had fallen in love with him.
Natásha feared this strange, unexpected happiness of meeting again the very man she had chosen.
Natásha was firmly convinced she had done so.
Natásha found that Prince Andrew was not indifferent to her.
Natásha said “And it had to happen that he should come specially to Petersburg while we are here.”
Natásha said “And it had to happen that we should meet at that ball.”
Natásha said “It is fate. Clearly it is fate that everything led up to this!”
Natásha said “Already then, directly I saw him I felt something peculiar.”
Natásha’s mother said “What else did he say to you? What are those verses? Read them...”
Natásha’s mother said “Mamma, one need not be ashamed of his being a widower?”
Natásha’s mother said “Don’t, Natásha! Pray to God. ‘Marriages are made in heaven,’”
Natásha said “Darling Mummy, how I love you! How happy I am!”
Natásha cried tears of joy and excitement and embraced her mother.
Prince Andrew was sitting with Pierre and telling Pierre of his love for Natásha and his firm resolve to make her his wife.
Countess Hélène had a reception at her house that day.
The French ambassador was there.
A foreign prince of the blood who had of late become a frequent visitor of Countess Hélène was there.
Many brilliant ladies and gentlemen were there.
Pierre walked through the rooms and struck everyone by his preoccupied, absent-minded, and morose air.
